name: Falling
description: A creature that falls takes 1d6 Bludgeoning damage at the end of the fall for every 10 feet it fell, to a maximum of 20d6. The creature lands with the Prone condition unless it avoids taking damage from the fall. A flying creature that has the Incapacitated or Prone condition or has its Speed reduced to 0 falls unless it can hover. A creature falls 500 feet instantly. If a creature starts falling and its fall doesn't end during the same turn, the creature falls 500 feet at the start of each of its subsequent turns. A creature that falls into water or another liquid can use its Reaction to make a DC 15 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check to enter the water gracefully. On a successful check, any damage resulting from the fall is halved.
shortDescription: Take 1d6 Bludgeoning per 10 ft fallen (max 20d6) and land Prone unless you avoid all damage from the fall.
rulesAsWritten: A creature that falls takes 1d6 Bludgeoning damage at the end of the fall for every 10 feet it fell, to a maximum of 20d6. The creature lands with the Prone condition unless it avoids taking damage from the fall.

conditionsImposed.note: Applied when a creature lands after a fall, unless the creature avoids taking damage from the fall.

relatedConditions.note: A creature that takes falling damage lands with the Prone condition.
A flying creature that has the Incapacitated condition falls unless it can hover.
A flying creature with the Prone condition falls unless it can hover.

applicationLogic.name: Falling Damage
applicationLogic.description: At the end of a fall, a creature takes 1d6 Bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it fell, to a maximum of 20d6 (200 feet). Fractional distances of less than 10 feet do not count toward damage.

trigger.condition: Creature reaches the end of a fall of 10 or more feet.

effects.description: The creature takes 1d6 Bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it fell, to a maximum of 20d6.
effects.mechanicalNote: Damage formula: floor(distance_in_feet / 10)d6 Bludgeoning, capped at 20d6. At 10 ft = 1d6, 20 ft = 2d6, ... 200 ft = 20d6. Beyond 200 ft the damage remains 20d6.

applicationLogic.name: Prone on Landing
applicationLogic.description: A creature that takes falling damage lands with the Prone condition unless it avoids taking damage from the fall entirely.

trigger.condition: Creature takes damage from a fall.

imposition.note: Applied upon landing if any falling damage was taken. Avoided only if the creature takes zero damage from the fall.

applicationLogic.name: Rate of Falling
applicationLogic.description: A creature falls 500 feet instantly. If a creature starts falling and the fall doesn't end during the same turn, the creature falls 500 feet at the start of each of its subsequent turns.

trigger.condition: Creature is currently in a state of falling that began on a previous turn.

effects.description: The creature falls 500 feet at the start of its turn. If it reaches a surface, the remaining fall resolves immediately with applicable falling damage.
effects.mechanicalNote: Initial fall is 500 feet instantaneous. Each subsequent turn the creature falls an additional 500 feet at the start of its turn. This means a 1,000-foot fall resolves across 2 turns.

applicationLogic.name: Flying Creature Falls
applicationLogic.description: A flying creature that has the Incapacitated or Prone condition, or has its Speed reduced to 0, falls unless it has the ability to hover.

trigger.condition: A flying creature gains the Incapacitated or Prone condition, or has its Speed reduced to 0, and it cannot hover.

effects.description: The flying creature immediately begins falling at the standard rate (500 feet instantly), unless it can hover.
effects.mechanicalNote: Hover capability negates this forced fall. Applies to any flight whether magical, natural, or granted by a spell.

applicationLogic.name: Falling into Water
applicationLogic.description: A creature that falls into water or another liquid can use its Reaction to make a DC 15 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check. On a successful check, any damage resulting from the fall is halved.

trigger.condition: Creature falls into water or another liquid and has a Reaction available.

effects.description: The creature may use its Reaction to attempt a DC 15 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check. On a success, all falling damage is halved. On a failure, full falling damage applies as normal.
effects.mechanicalNote: Costs a Reaction. DC 15 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check. Success: total falling damage is halved (round down). Failure: full damage. Only applicable when landing in water or another liquid.

stacking.stackingNote: Falling damage is a single event resolved at the end of a fall. Multiple falls are separate events, each resolved independently.

dmNotes: Falling damage is always Bludgeoning. The maximum of 20d6 (average 70, max 120) represents terminal velocity. A creature that is immune to Bludgeoning damage or avoids all damage from the fall (e.g., via Feather Fall or a Monk's Slow Fall) does not land Prone. The 500-feet-per-round rate gives creatures a brief window to react to a very long fall (e.g., casting Feather Fall). Determine whether partial 10-foot increments round downâ€”RAW only full 10-foot increments count.

commonRulings.question: Does a creature that is immune to Bludgeoning damage still land Prone from a fall?
commonRulings.ruling: No. The creature avoids taking damage from the fall, so the Prone condition is not applied.

commonRulings.question: Does the Feather Fall spell prevent the Prone condition from falling?
commonRulings.ruling: Yes. Feather Fall reduces the falling damage to 0, and since the creature avoids taking damage from the fall, it does not land Prone.

commonRulings.question: Can a creature fall more than 500 feet on the first turn?
commonRulings.ruling: No. A creature falls 500 feet instantly. Any remaining distance is covered at the start of subsequent turns at 500 feet per turn.

commonRulings.question: Does falling provoke Opportunity Attacks?
commonRulings.ruling: No. Falling is not voluntary movement using your Speed, action, or Reaction, so it does not provoke Opportunity Attacks.
